stem: A 34-week-pregnant client with preeclampsia is being evaluated for worsening malaise. Based on the documentation in the OB-HELLP & Peripheral Smear Log, which finding is the most definitive indicator of Hemolysis?

tabs.title: Peripheral Blood Smear
tabs.content: Impression: Presence of **Schistocytes** (fragmented, helmet-shaped red blood cells). Marked polychromasia. Low overall RBC count.

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content: Current: Sclera are mildly icteric (jaundiced). Urine is dark and 'coca-cola' colored. Client reports 'pain under the right ribs.'

options.text: The presence of schistocytes on the peripheral blood smear
The report of pain under the right ribs (RUQ)

rationale.correct: This is the **'H' (Hemolysis) in HELLP Syndrome (a1)**. While high LDH and Bilirubin suggest cell breakdown, the most definitive visual/clinical indicator of hemolysis is the presence of **Schistocytes (a1)** on a blood smear. These are fragmented red blood cells that have been 'shredded' as they pass through small, fibrin-clotted vessels. This microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a hallmark of the transition from simple preeclampsia to the life-threatening HELLP syndrome.
clinicalPearls: HELLP: H (Hemolysis), EL (Elevated Liver enzymes), LP (Low Platelets).
Low Haptoglobin: Haptoglobin 'mops up' free hemoglobin; when it's low, it means it's all used up from massive hemolysis.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing RUQ pain (a3) because it's a 'red flag.'
questionTrap.howToOvercome: RUQ pain indicates the **EL** (Elevated Liver enzymes/Liver swelling) part of HELLP, but not Specifically the **H** (Hemolysis). Always match the lab indicator to the specific component of the syndrome.

mnemonic.title: HE-LL-P Smear
mnemonic.expansion: HE-Hemolysis. LL-Liver Low. P-Platelets. Smear-Schistocytes (Broken Cells).
